title: 5ive singer Scott Robinson had condition that left him 'scared of salad and fruit'
text:

As a member of the best-selling boy band 5ive, Scott ­Robinson ­travelled the globe, ­staying in the best hotels with access to fine ­dining every night of the week.

The group – who signed to Simon Cowell with a six-album deal – enjoyed the high life and sold 1.6 million albums, with Top 10 hits including Keep On Movin’ and Slam Dunk (Da Funk).

But while his bandmates regularly relished nights out at the world’s top restaurants, Scott didn’t join them, instead preferring to go back to his hotel room alone with a can of soup.

At the time Scott believed he was simply a fussy eater.

Only now does the singer realise he was suffering ARFID (Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder).

A newly diagnosed condition, ARFID hit the headlines when it was revealed a teenager suffered sight loss as a result of his restricted diet.

In Scott’s case, until he sought help two years ago, he could not remember a time he had eaten fresh vegetables. Neither had he tried salad, rice or any dish containing a sauce, such as lasagne or curry. Fruit, other than apples, was also off the menu.

(Image: Press Association)

“It wasn’t that I didn’t like all these foods, I was actually scared of them,” Scott, 39, recalls. “It was the texture that put me off and a fear of being sick.

“I would say ‘I won’t be able to swallow it’. I remember someone once persuading me to try porridge and I had the gag reflex as I put it in my mouth. I was like that with a lot of foods.

“I look back now and think of the ­seriously good meals I could have ­experienced, but in those days I just couldn’t enjoy it. The rest of the band would get frustrated.”

Scott resorted to filling his suitcase with tins of Heinz tomato soup when they went on tour. “If the other guys went out for dinner I’d stay in my room,” he says.

“I’d go into the hotel kitchens and ask them to warm it up for me, but I’d stand over them to make sure they didn’t put anything else into it. I didn’t even try pepper until I was 24.”

A key issue with ARFID is that sufferers can’t stand the texture, smell, taste or appearance of certain foods.

The fear is often so severe it causes a physiological constriction of the mouth, throat and digestive tract. It is often triggered by a distressing experience with food, such as choking or vomiting, and Scott believes that’s what happened to him.

“When I was seven I liked tuna ­sandwiches, but only made with vinegar,” he remembers.

“My Nan made me some with vinegar and she also made my Granddad some with salad cream. He swapped one, thinking it wouldn’t matter, and when I bit into the one with salad cream I was violently sick. I’m still scared of salad cream now.”

(Image: Getty Images)

Scott’s parents tried to tempt him by putting new foods on his plate, but he steadfastly refused to try them. Their fears grew when he joined 5ive aged 18.

“Obviously then there was nothing they could do,” he says. “I was the other side of the world and ­struggling to eat. I was skinny and I remember on one occasion I met them halfway through a tour and when I arrived at the airport they looked at me in shock – I'd lost so much weight.

“The problem was a buffet would be laid on for us. I wouldn’t like anything and there wasn’t time for me to order something different as we’d need to move on to the next place, be it a radio station or a gig.”

When Scott married his wife Kerry in 2005, things failed to improve. “For breakfast I’d have Coco Pops, lunch would be beans on white toast with a little bit of cheese, and dinner would be a plain burger with chips or a plain steak with mashed potato.”

The couple, who live in Essex, have four children, sons Brennan, 18 and Kavan, 13, and five-year-old twin girls Bobbi-Raye and Kayde-Rose, who all enjoy a varied diet.

“Kerry didn’t want the kids to be the same as me,” Scott says.

“The girls eat everything. For a little while the boys would copy me, but then they started eating everything.”

Two years ago Kerry had hypnosis to conquer a severe fear of flying and Scott decided to book a session to see if it would help him with his food phobia.

“I was approaching 40 and I thought ‘enough is enough’,” he explains.

While sceptical, after five sessions he was able to order a curry for the first time. “It had sauce and onions in it. These were things I wouldn’t have dreamed of putting on my plate, let alone in my mouth,” he recalls.

“The difference has been incredible. Now, even if I still don’t like certain foods I’m no longer scared of trying most things.”

(Image: DAILY MIRROR)

Scott now eats lasagne, veg such as carrots and peas, and home-made leek and potato soup. “In a ridiculous way I feel proud of myself,” he smiles.

He is now considering returning to hypnotherapy as not all of his fears are conquered. “I can’t touch mayonnaise or salad cream and I think I’d vomit if I ate prawns or any seafood,” he says.

Scott has suffered no health issues as a result of his restricted diet, but wishes more had been known about the ­condition as he was growing up, enabling him to get help earlier.

He says: “I wish it hadn’t just been, ‘oh Scott’s a fussy eater’. I wish I had known there was something causing it,” he says.

In recent years 5ive have reformed and next year head out on a 30-date The Boys Are Back Tour, alongside boy bands 911, A1 and Damage.

One of the pleasures for Scott is he can now sit down and eat dinner with his bandmates.

“I didn’t tell them I was having ­hypnotherapy,” he says. “We were doing a gig in Scotland and we had a buffet and I put some chilli and rice on my plate. They stopped, open-mouthed as I shovelled it in.”

description: EXCLUSIVE: Scott Robinson suffered Avoidant Restrictive Food Intake Disorder, a newly diagnosed condition where sufferers can't stand the texture, smell, taste or appearance of certain foods
